When Is a Wart Hog A Canned Pork Product?

Not often in the course of American litigation have the words ''good-natured wart hog'' appeared. Ditto ''evil in porcine form'' and ''nasty pagan brute.'' But the battle of Hormel Foods Corporation v. Jim Henson Productions Inc. -- affectionately known as Spam v. Spa'am -- was not your average case.
Still, it attracted little public attention as it wended its way through three federal courts.

Hormel, the maker of Spam, the canned luncheon meat, said it was worried about being confused with Spa'am, one of Miss Piggy's tribal guards in the ''Muppet Treasure Island'' movie. So worried that it sued for trademark infringement.

The three-day trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan in 1995 revealed just how seriously one can take canned meat. Testifying for Hormel, Laura A. Peracchio, a consumer behavior expert, said ''Spa'am is unappealing and will lead to negative associations on the part of consumers because he has small eyes, protruding teeth, warts, a skull on his headdress, is generally untidy and speaks in a deep voice with poor grammar and diction.''

Judge Kimba Wood, however, was more persuaded by Anne Devereaux Jordan, an expert in children's literature, who noted that kids like characters that are not classically handsome, like ''Pumbaa, the good-natured wart hog in another kids' movie, 'The Lion King.' '' While Hormel found Spa'am unhygienic, the judge found him merely sloppy.
Hormel argued that Henson ''falsely personifies Spam as a nasty pagan brute,'' and expressed fear that sales of Spam would drop off if it were linked with, yes, ''evil in porcine form.''

Judge Wood and the judges of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, who upheld her ruling, found that Hormel had already proved it could withstand bad Spam jokes. ''In a recent newspaper column,'' the appeals court wrote, ''it was noted that 'In one little can, Spam contains the five major food groups: Snouts. Ears. Feet. Tails. Brains.' In view of the more or less humorous takeoffs such as these, one might think Hormel would welcome the association with a genuine source of pork.''

Adding that Spam is eaten in 30 percent of American homes, the judges said, ''To the extent that Spam is popular and highly regarded by consumers, as Hormel claims, that popularity exists in spite of a media barrage of highly negative humor at Spam's expense.''
For the people behind the Muppets, the dispute was a tempest in a pigpen.

''He was a bit character in a background scene in a movie,'' said Peter Schube, general counsel for the Henson Company. The boar's name came up only once in the film, and Spa'am hasn't made a screen appearance since.

Spam v. Spa'am never made it to the United States Supreme Court, which declined to review the appeals court decision. That's too bad, really. The case would have been right at home in a city known for its pork barrel, hams -- and the occasional good-natured wart hog.
A Political Dispute Ends Quietly

When Deborah I. Volberg, formerly acting general counsel of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, was asked to come up with a list of lawyers who could be fired after the Pataki administration took office in 1995, she recommended some who had very likely been hired for their political connections. Her bosses wanted to dismiss others, who had been hired more recently and had no political clout. Ms. Volberg pointed out that many of these lawyers were black, Asian or Hispanic.
She was promptly fired herself. She sued, arguing that she lost her job over politics instead of performance.
Her lawyer, Jonathan Lovett, said the case was eventually dismissed without a trial. Ms. Volberg, now in private practice in White Plains, would not comment on the case.
TINA KELLEY
